critique: This executive order, issued by President Clinton, aims to enforce UN Security Council resolutions against UNITA, a group in Angola. It restricts transactions and activities involving UNITA and certain areas of Angola, primarily focusing on aviation-related activities. The order invokes the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) and the National Emergencies Act, indicating a national security concern. It does not directly address immigration, social inclusion, or economic regulation within the US. The order grants authority to the Secretary of the Treasury to implement the restrictions. It can be argued that this expands executive power, although it is in line with international agreements and UN resolutions. The order does not seem to have a strong ideological tilt. It is primarily focused on foreign policy and national security.
